comment: Caramel and vanilla followed by lots of spice.  Long finish. calms down when you add an ice cube.
Dark cherry on the nose and ballpark peanuts on the palate tonight. BIN
Hot hot hot.  I could not get past the burn.  Not my style

Taste:  1 oz. in glen cairn first and then addition of 3 drops distilled water then rested for 15 minutes.

Nose (3.75):  Initial nose is a full on caramel, butterscotch,  oak and ethanol. Traditional bourbon nose.  Very upfront and not very complex.  The ethanol hits you hard.  Let it air out.

Palate:  (4.25)  Straight out of the bottle it tends to be hot.  The ethanol is strong and the palate intensifies from what's on the nose.  I was not overwhelmingly approving of the palate without cutting it.  Resting it with some water was different story entirely.  Transformed the experience to taste bit-o-honey, candied apple, intensified the butterscotch.  The ethanol and heat were just the right amount then.  Again not a puzzling or complex bourbon, but just what you would want if you love to drink traditional aged bourbon that hasn't been amped up by an additional finish in a "spirit of the day" cask or sloshed around on a ship for awhile.  Tastes from this one seem to be all barrel magic.

Finish (4.0):  When neat it was super spicy.  Surprised me with spice and I must admit made me cough just a little.  When neat it was a 3/5 and a little rough.  With water and 15 minutes of patience it is a downright 4-5.  Damn fine whisky!

Overall-  Definately a Heavan Hill product here without doubt.  Reminds me of Elijah Craig Barrel Proof and checks all the flavor profile boxes of quality Heaven Hill product.  Well constructed and very pleasing.  Water simply transforms it.  My advice is that if you see it at MSRP ($40-45) buy it and bunker a few bottles.  The word is getting out on this one because it is a sleeper and like the ECBP my guess is that it will head upwards of $60 and be on allocation by next year.  The secondary market will be looking hard for it.  Great bourbon to be on the ground floor with
Good burn straight, oaky vanilla with some brown sugar and caramel. Butterscotch finish.
This is Cracker Jacks from Nose to taste all day! For 40.00 and having some great flavor profile you can’t bet this. Well done and love the age statement not much around like that anymore
Sweet caramel start. Strong finish. Great deep amber color.

Muted nose at first. Sweet notes. Opens up with time, classic notes. On the palate, nice spice, some dough, a surprising young note. Some citrus. Wood at the end, some bitterness. Spice lingers. This is nice, if straightforward. 11/30/18
SUPER smooth for the ABV, but just way too sweet for my taste. However, I do think they’ve really created something that a lot of whiskey drinkers will enjoy.
Its sweet with lots of butterscotch and vanilla on the tongue. Then you get a dose of cinnamon and Caramel with a nice long lasting warm finish. Surprisingly smooth for a higher proof.

It is very smooth for how strong the proof is with a mile burn at the back of the throat (aka. Kentucky hug). The palate is not as deep and complex as I would like. It has the standard bourbon tastes, but for the price of roughly $50. It is worth it. This would be a good daily drinker in my opinion.  I tried this neat.

117 proof 7 year old bourbon from Kentucky.   Although Luxco has a “distillery” now, this is sourced from somewhere.  Heaven Hill seems to be the lead suspect.  In an age of no age statements, it’s nice to see some of the dying breed.

N:  Oak, vanilla, toffee, cinnamon, orange peel.

P:  Toffee, pralines, brown sugar, vanilla, oranges.

F:  Oak, allspice, toffee, burnt sugar.

A chip off the ‘ole block.  Pretty much what you would expect, if you’ve ever had the (now discontinued) 101 proof version of this.  Similar to JW Dant Bonded as well.  Heavy on the pralines and brown sugar.  People seem to be getting excited about this in some of bourbon groups online, but I’m not sure why.  It’s decent in my opinion, but nothing to get excited about.  It is a pretty good value though.  A 117 proof bourbon for $35 to $40 nowadays is pretty rare - plus it has a 7 year age statement which is right around the 8 to 12 year wheelhouse where good bourbons usually are found.

Truly a fantastic barrel proof bourbon! Traditional notes of vanilla, caramel, lots of oak (which I love), cinnamon spice and hints of leather. Incredibly smooth neat, long warming finish without any burn. My fave mid priced barrel proof and go to remains WT Rare Breed however, this is firmly right behind it. What a great find! Enjoy

Fun fact:

I bought this bottle at least a month ago for $38 at my local liquor store. There are still bottles on the shelf. 15 minutes away, there’s a liquor store selling the same bottle for $250. Don’t fall for it.

That said, this bottle delivers for $40. Nose is floral and sweet, like honeysuckle. Body tastes like powdered sugar, and finish carries a nice cinnamon buzz.

With water added:

Body opens up a bit. I get more vanilla and less pure sugary sweetness. Finish is greatly diminished, and for my 2-cents-worth, not in a good way. I think I prefer this one neat, which is a bit unusual for me. If I could shoehorn the body once water was added, to the nose and finish when poured neat, that would be ideal.
This is just a solid bourbon. The elevated proof lends a lushness to mouthfeel. This is smooth. Lingering finish of barrel notes helps to balance the vanilla sweetness. Just solid! Get you some.
Sweet on the front with a non complex easy drinking bourbon. Watering in brings some heat to the party but not over the top
Surprising caramel and sweetness despite the high proof. Smooth finish with nice amount of peppery burn.
Not as warm as other barrel proofs. More drinkable than most as well
Great barrel strength bourbon for the price.  I get a lot of sweetness and vanilla on the palate.
Needs a few drops of water. Good sweetness, alcohol is hidden well.

The nose is heavy on honey with a bit of mint. 

Undiluted it's very silky with a short hot finish. Lots of oak flavor with almost almond butter toast.

Diluted with a few drops of water, the nose changes to butterscotch. Slightly less silky, but gets more heat and pepper mid and fades to oak, honey, and slight vanilla.

Starts off as a cinnamon bomb when first opened, then settles into a sea of damp musty oak and vanilla after it’s had time to breathe. Hey Plenty of dense oak, cinnamon, sawdust, brown sugar, vanilla, leather, sweet black coffee, intense brown butter and butterscotch. Rich and mouth coating. Spicy and warm, very soothing long finish
Nose is apples and caramel. Palate is fruits, sweet notes of vanilla, and char. Alcohol burn is strong on this one.
You can taste the corn sweetness in this one. Good barrel proof for the price. It tastes a bit young but I would buy again at $40.
Enjoyable drink. I like it whether I dilute it or drink it neat. Has a nice mouthful, an oily texture once diluted. Subtle burn...
Sweet vanilla, savory fig and rich caramel. Nice spice and heat. Long finish that hovers on the tastebuds for a while. Very nice.

The nose is mostly oak, leather, toffee, peanuts, very little ethanol. Peanuts become more prevalent with time in the glass. The palate is fairly thin and dry. Lots of oak followed by leather. Caramel and smoke try to break through, but stay in the background. Again, really no warmth except for the transition to the finish. The finish has leather, caramel, smoke, all in a really nice balance. A little warm. Everything lingers for a long while. Really nice finish.

Wow! This is really good. Vanilla and toffee on the nose and dark fruit (fig/dates) in the palate along with vanilla. I understand the term chewy now. This really opens up aroma wise with a splash of water, which really tames the hotness. I loved this pour!!!

Nose: Fall Spices. Cinnamon, Orange Peel, Dried Peaches, Burnt Sugar, Clove and a good dose of Oak.
Neat: Thick and Chewy. Nearly all of the notes from the nose carry over with a peanut butter note joining in. A healthy dose of Oak Tannins make this a tick on the astringent side. Lots of heat, but in a good sense. 
Finish: Goes down with a nice warming in the chest. Leaves bitter spice along the sides of the tongue. Coats the rest of the palate with a hint of  lingering musty oak that I really like and find in most older Heaven Hill products (McK 10 year, Evan Williams Single Barrel, Rebel Yell 10 year).
Splash: Very beneficial... Brings a little more depth to the palate. You get hints of the traditional butterscotch and toffee. Allows the oak note to rise above the heat as well without killing that peppery spice on the end.
Verdict?: I found this very similar to Elijah Craig Barrel Proof. Dare I say, "Poor Man's Elijah Craig BP"? If this can be found at the suggested retail of $40, it's a no-brainer. My fear is that this will follow the model of Rebel Yell 10 year and spike in price after the initial release. I do want to say that whoever is in charge of recent bottle/label design and marketing at LuxCo is doing a great job, especially with the Ezra Brooks line. If they can maintain this level of quality with their own distillate, this will be a company to reckon with moving forward.

Luxco, sourced from Heaven Hill and/or Beam. Aroma is loads of caramel and vanilla with a bit of sawdust and wood. The palate has a peppery bite. Overall very good, both straight and as a mixer. This is a great value. Add a drop of water to this and it changes a bit. Something like Beam funk in the aroma.

This is really enjoyable for sipping, even at its high proof. Thick texture and loads of your common bourbon flavors. There is a long burn, but it never overwhelms the flavors. Really good pour and a great price

Back a few years ago, I discovered this bourbon's forebear, the Old Ezra 7 Year standard bottling, which continues to be a heck of a bargain. When I heard that they were releasing a barrel strength version, my excitement was visceral...and became nearly uncontrollable when folks like Fred Minnick started singing its glories. At long last, it made it to Wisconsin...and I snapped up the first bottle I found.

It's as good as I'd hoped. The nose is the Platonic form of bourbon nose - loads of baking spice, baked cherry, vanilla, caramel, black pepper, leather. There's a little nose hair-tweaking heat, but it's not an overly boozy nose for the abv. If the nose is good, the taste is even better. This is what bourbon is supposed to be - rich, coating, buttery, positively exploding with character. You want spices? You got it. Vanilla? Yup. Caramel? It practically oozes out of your mouth. Woody, leathery notes? Just enough to lend some complexity without hitting you over the head. Nuttiness? Present. It's like pecan pie in a glass. The finish lasts a nice, long while, too.

This is good. Damn good. So damn good. And, for $40-ish a bottle? Get out of town.
Reminds me too much of HH BIB. Rrgognize it's great price point with a flavor profile most others like. However, I find it chalky. A bit more spice than HH BIB which I did enjoy.

This is really nice. Strong vanilla on the nose. Vanilla and caramel on the palate, quickly followed by a sharp burn on the tongue that doesn’t burn down the throat. Totally a perfect classic bourbon. Now halfway through the bottle and I get a small hint of peanut on the finish, though not as strong as Booker’s. Really nice one to have on hand. 

Lucky to get this on sale at $31.99.

N: Quite sweet. Orange, vanilla, butterscotch, oak, leather, little bit of pepper. 
P: Tons of Barrel on the palate which is surprising for only 7 yrs. Nice amounts of sweet oak and leather. The proof really starts to ramp up mid palate and lingers with a nice finish isn’t too long and really invites you in for another taste. Can’t complain with this at its retail price. Well done.

Nose: strong alcohol that drowns out other more subtle notes. Maybe some cinnamon and cloves but could be my imagination

Mouthfeel: thick and chewy with some softness 

Taste: subtle up front with some raisin and cinnamon, immediately drowned out by strong flush of ethanol, heat, and spice the second it touches oxygen. Fire goes out quickly with a subtle muted finish for a barrel proof. Better after it opens up a bit, but maybe a smidge over hyped
Well balanced, good to drink straight, perfect strength, oily and sweet but strong

Will probably regret this later when you can't find it, but this is a steal for $40. Same flavor profile as the Joseph Magnus at half the cost, with a bit more caramel/vanilla on the palate. The heat isn't bad at all for the higher proof.
Strong scent. A little burn but a smooth transition. Not a great flavor, but smooth.

Nice char, as you drink it dark chocolate elements come out.  I added quite a bit of water this time.  The flavor is pleasant and mellow - there is a definite anise flavor from the rye, which unfolds into spice with a little more bite.
Nose is maple, butter, and sugar. Toasted pecans and cinnamon on the taste with mouthy finish and medium burn.

A wonderfully cacophonous whiskey that felt high pitched in tone, with a subtly tart quality beneath a pleasantly smooth start to finish. I get cherries clearly with a hint of licorice (anise) on the finish. On the nose, I'm reminded of a wet, mossy forest. 

The high corn bill is unmistakable.  Very lown burn for something only 7 years old. Worth the price I paid.
Might have over payed, but my bottle is signed by the master distiller:)
A good sipper and great value for a barrel proof bourbon.    Distinct flavor here, reminiscent of peanuts near the finish.  But in a good way.

Cherries on the nose
Lighter taste with a good burn and mouthfeel. Short finish but tasty!

Whiskey Club - Doug’s house
Great nose
Oaky but not overly so; great mouthfeel with peanut finish. Easy drinking for the proof

My favorite bourbon — despite the higher proof, the Old Ezra 7-Year sips very smooth and has just the right flavor profile. No heavy ethanol on the nose, no harshness on the tongue, no burn going down.

I was compelled to buy this one after a friend sent me an article that discussed the 2018 bourbon of the year. This one beat out Elijah Craig Barrel Proof, which, though I'd yet to try it, had enough of a reputation to get me interested in this Old Ezra. After seeing it at a very reasonable $45, I pulled the trigger.

Nose: Traditional bourbon notes turned up a notch. Very rich. Big-time caramel, brown sugar, and oak. I'm not sure what the mash bill is here, but the corn notes really come through. Beneath that, I get new couch leather and tobacco. A trace of vanilla. Great nose.

Palate: Heavy caramel, vanilla, butterscotch, peanut, and sweet cola. Shockingly easy-going upon arrival. This changes, however, when the spice kicks in on the mid-palate. Lots of cinnamon, as well as nutmeg and other baking spices. Oak is prominent throughout.

Finish: Medium-to-long. Maybe a tad shorter than I was expecting considering the ABV, but it's still very respectable. Spicy cinnamon hits hard. The charcoal-mellowing also shows up here. While I can identify the same characteristic that I get in Jack Daniel's products, it's done infinitely better in this one.

Bourbon of the year? Maybe. I'd probably take the Elijah Craig (though to be fair the one I picked up was 2017). However, this is half the price of that one, and really not all that far behind. This one punches well above its weight class in terms of quality, but has is as drinkable as far weaker bourbons. At $45 it's a no-brainer, and quite possibly the best value of 2018. If you're into bourbon, pick this one up. It will not disappoint.

Edit: I've finally finished this one 3 months after cracking. After some oxidation, I must say that it has only gotten better with time. I've decided to bump it from 4.75 to 5 stars because it's amazingly balanced and comes at a ridiculously low price when you consider what's inside.

Look: Light amber orange, really a lot lighter than most barrel strength bourbons I’ve encountered. There’s some alcohol legs showing on the glass

Nose: First thing I get is cinnamon followed by more rye ala clove. Vanilla comes in bringing some sweetness.

Palate: leads off with that rye presence of baking spices cinnamon and of course vanilla.  Oak comes into play near the finish more

Finish: Not as hot as one would expect for a barrel proofer.  Pepper cinnamon oak flavor on the finish, mid bitterness from the wood, with a long lasting finish of the previously mentioned flavors.  There’s some heat but again not what you’d expect on this.  
Overall: An extremely easy drinking barre proof with a good amount of flavor, and low price tag. What’s not to love?

Nose: boozy caramel and slight nuttiness
Taste: boozy spiciness and ever so slightly vanilla on the finish

The nose is a wonderful mix of marzipan, cherry, fig, oak, molasses and a hint of dried flowers and mint. The palate is dry but rich and very creamy, with intense baking spices, caramel, vanilla and the slightest hint of fruit at the end. The finish is medium long with fading marzipan and baking spices, with buttery caramel and oak behind it. Delicious.
Delicious pour. The nose and palette both bring spicy cinnamon and pepper courtesy of the rye. Also noticed is oak, leather, vanilla. Nice burn but not very substantial or long.
Oh my goodness, coconut/hazelnut cake? Dark cherry, hickory - lite smoke. Sweet and delicious, a must buy if you haven’t tried it yet
For 117 I think this is pretty smooth. Chocolate and cherries.
Great aroma. A little harsher to drink than other bourbons. Hits the nose pretty hard on the front end.

The nose is pure bulk bin store peanut butter—mostly the oil. Surprisingly little ethanol vapor for the proof, and easy to huff. Palate is more peanut butter with some vanilla and brown sugar, and a little touch of citrus. Finish is spicy and dry, short to medium length and yep—more peanut butter. Lacking the complexity I’d hoped for.
A good inexpensive every day drink

You can definitely tell there's a large corn base here. It's for sure hot on the taste, but that's simply because of the barrel strength. Overly sweet if you're basing it on smell, but the alcohol balances it well with a psydo rye flavor. Not so much wood flavor as compared to higher years of age.
Okay smell, tingly on the tongue. Strait forward and solid
Very strong spice on the palate, overall great choice of bourbon for the price point. Unusually smooth for the high proof. Great vanilla finish!
Vanilla, Cherry Cola, peanut, peanut butter

Odd but yet enticing mossy vegetal note on the nose along with vanilla, nut, and ginger. Some sourness on the tongue along with candy sweetness resulting in a flavor not unlike a pickle dipped in caramel vanilla sauce. Some barrel char and savory notes like honey baked ham as well. Finishes with cashew nut and toasted marshmallow and some heat from the proof. A lot going on here. Very tasty.

At $35 at TW in my area, this is an insane value. The fact that this bourbon is my substitute for Knob Creek 14yr store picks (pretty much cleared out in AZ) should tell you something.
I’m in love. Honey roasted almonds... cake battered butter (???)  an absolute steal if you find it at msrp, still a steal at 100 on secondary in my opinion

Bought 2 bottles and just opened number 1.....this juice is legit......lots of ethanol on the nose, but the palate makes up for it: a ton of classic bourbon flavors but with a unique finish thanks to the charcoal mellowing. Reminiscent of JD Old No. 7, but much more spectacular. Good sweetness, layers of complexity, and a unique taste that keeps bringing me back for more. Don’t miss this one if you like higher proof bourbon and can find one in the wild. I was fortunate to find it at two different stores at MSRP ($40). This is not a wimpy pour......lights up your palate in a major way and reminds you what’s good about life.
Barrel strength so big proof but it doesn't finish that way.  The warmth spreads out with a big flavor.  Digging this.
Lots of heat and spice. But also lots of vanilla and brown sugar

Nose: oak, spice (cinnamon), vanilla, cigar

Taste: spiced nuts (like the candied ones you get at the fair), oak, tobacco, some caramel once it opens up

Overall SO much better than its predecessor Old Ezra 7 101 proof, but definitely not a go-to bourbon for me. Also pretty smooth for barrel strength!

Cherry on the nose, more rich than it’s 101 predecessor. Vanilla and a slight tobacco or anise flavor on the taste, I’m not good enough to know for sure. Coats your tongue, gives a nice burn, and finishes more bitter than sweet.
One of the best bourbons I have ever had.  Heat and spice and oaky finish.  Warm Kentucky hug. Not a lot of floral or fruit notes.  Cinnamon and slightly nutty
Spicy with cinnamon and brown sugar.  Oaky char finish
Nose is sweet, fruity, and smoky. Get scents of bananas. Smoke continued on the palate with hints of spicy oak. Long spicy finish with some sweetness at the end.

N: sweet corn, clove and cinnamon, hints of apples and acetone. After sitting out, caramel

P: Rye grain and oak upfront, very hot mid palate

F: Charcoal smoky, oak and hints of white pepper

Dry on the finish, flavors come back in waves. Fruit and baking spice really come out on the nose with a few drops of water, but flavor is very similar.
Carmel brittle, Oaky, nice bite but not overly powering for a cast strength.
This has a gentle warmth to it, but the cinnamon spice with sweet brown sugar notes makes me want to pair with a warm Toll House cookie. Definitely a must buy in the $40-$45 range.
great Bourbon for price.  easily worth 45 -50
Deep, rich, flavorful. Not for amateurs! A real bourbon!
Dad picked up, tried on Mother’s Day weekend. Solid bottle, 117 proof. No strong alcohol burn, a little spicy, unique flavor
Strong cask-strength flavor with vanilla, oak, and Smokey notes
Really enjoyed this. Wanting to try it next to old forester 1920.
Warm and toastie. This is a campfire in a bottle. I could drink this every day
This is good. Drinks easy for its proof. Long spicy finish. Great value bourbon for a single barrel high proof.
Lingering burn in the throat, but good.

Neat.  Peanut.  Buttery popcorn.  Tons of vanilla on the nose.  Nice creamy texture. Vanilla, caramel, cinnamon, charred oak.  Rich and strong finish.  Barely shows its proof anywhere too.

This lives up to the hype.  Hot damn.

Absolutely fantastic classic bourbon flavors at barrel strength....waves of cinnamon, vanilla, butterscotch, leather, and oak coat the tongue...still affordable and relatively easy to find if you put your mind to it but obviously is becoming more highly allocated...

Strong alcohol on the nose first followed by butterscotch. The palate is sweet with butterscotch and vanilla. Smooth finish 
With 1 ice cube it is like a whole different dram. All sweet.

I have long moaned about the fact that on the west coast we are slow to receive distribution of a lot of newer Bourbon releases. This is a good example of this issue. This Bourbon has been out for months, picked up numerous awards (including best straight Bourbon at the 2019 SF Spirits Competition) and this is the very first time I have seen it in the Phoenix market. $1 over SRP makes it an instant buy for me. So does it live up to the hype? We will get into that shortly. First some background:
Mashbill: 78% corn, 12% malted barley and 10% rye.
Age Stated at 7 yrs
Distillery undisclosed (rumored to be Heaven Hill)
117 proof
It is Charcoal Mellowed (chill filtered) 
Distribution by Luxco (Rebel Yell, Blood Oath etc)
On to the tasting:
On the palatte it's very rich and sweet with classic Bourbon notes of toffee, vanilla and burnt brown sugar. The heat is very evident on the mid palette which adds oak, barrel spice and a rich toffee note. The finish is pretty long with plenty of heat, oak, more barrel spice and a lingering toffee dipped cherry note. 
I can just picture an old west scene with the main character sipping on a Bourbon like this. It's definitely one that puts hair on your chest. It's classic, simple, hot Kentucky Bourbon. I found that adding water or ice took away from the experience. This is one for someone with experience drinking Barrel Proof Bourbon. It's like a better OGD 114. The heat reminds of the older Booker's batches. It's hot, but in a good way if that makes sense. 
So in summation, is this on the ECBP, Stagg Jr, Booker's level? In short no. But it's also considerably cheaper. 
At $40-$45 it's an outstanding value. However, let me be clear, it's not worth paying above the odds and nor are you getting something that will blow you away. Keeping all that in mind, it's a must have to any high proof Bourbon lovers shelf. All things considered (most importantly price paid) this one gets a solid 4/5. Happy to have finally found this. Cheers all and TGIF
sweet, with a lot of good flavor. a lot of vanilla, then a rush of heat

Smell - apples, cherries similar to Evan Williams SiB, cinnamon

Taste - tastes like bookers. Good flavor, very hot, cherries. A little tobacco. Great flavor. Cinnamon comes through as well with some peppermint.
It’s got a bit on an off taste to me, maybe too ethanol or too much vanilla. Not sure 117 proof
I dont normally add water but this one benefits from a couple drops it brings out a lot more of the good flavors and actually made my tongue tingle all over.
Strong, very tasty with a strong finish
For $35 this is a must buy. Drink it straight... mix it, whatever you like. It works well.
Not much better than old Ezra but also bad
Great! A fraction of the price of Barrell infinite Barrell April 2018 but with a similar and arguably better taste. The finish is smoother than Barrell.

This is really great whiskey!  Cinnamon abounds.(I love cinnamon). Flavor after flavor.  The finish is like having Dentyne gum in your mouth.  When tasting, there is no way to guess it is 117 proof.  It has 117 flavor and drinks like a 90.  A very good deal for $45 in NC.

Nose: tobacco, leather, baking spice - spicier than cinnamon but not quite clove, black tea, anise
Taste: vanilla, malty, oak
Finish: hot, oak
After reading reviews: I didn’t find this as sweet as the reviews suggest.  Cherry did make sense on the taste once I saw that.  Fig may be what I got as maltiness - reminiscent of a scotch note.  Wonderful nose, but a little too much barrel bitterness from the oak for my taste keeps it from being great overall.
So much vanilla. Good fruit flavor as well. Super good

Nose: Extremely accessible for sitting at 117 proof. You can really dig your nose all the way into the glass without feeling like you burned off your nose. Notes of brown sugar toffee with nuts, creamy corn, fig newtons, and spicy Mexican vanilla engulf the nose. Underneath, the oak stands it ground with remnants of nutmeg and burnt toast. 

Palate: All the fig, corn, nuts and toffee transfer to the initial and mid-palate. The notes stay centered as well. This is mouth watering and savory, accessing umami flavors. Even though there is a lot of flavor here, it still stays lighter and more inviting than most barrel proof expressions.

Finish: A nice Kentucky Hug takes its grip on your chest, but the burn is surprisingly minimal. The flavors from the nose linger past your bedtime. The spicy vanilla and toffee notes swell and stick with you for at least a minute or two. 

Overall, this is solid as they come. The price point keeps you coming back for more. I like seeing a respectful age-statement, 7-years, which in today's world is a good age. I believe this is sourced from Heaven Hill by Lux Row Distillers.
Nose is BBQ sauce, Woody, fruity and sweet. Brings some heat on the back of the tongue, along with brown sugar and pepper. Nice, slightly bitter.

Tobacco, cherry, vanilla, and a dried fruit (I can’t put my finger on it) come through on the nose. Oak and honey dominate the palate in a balanced way. The finish is medium in length, and a hint of raw corn is followed immediately by more tobacco. Incredibly smooth for 117 proof.
Very good.  An ice cube really opened it up for me.  Easy sipper with the charcoal mellowing showing thru.
I think this selection is underrated.   Neat or with a rock, the texture is well blended and the finish is enjoyable.
Very flavorful.  Long finish. Really enjoyed it!

Too much alcohol to taste anything else. If you add water it is better, but more than a drop is needed. I’ll pass on another bottle.
2 months later and I am so happy to see this bottle go. I gave the last pour to a buddy, he dumped it. I don’t blame him, the only reason I didn’t do that is because I paid 40 beans for it.
Fool me once....... you know the rest.

Ordered at a bar, served in a rocks glass.
Nose has a decent amount of vanilla sweetness and some brown sugar. Along with alcohol burn.
The palate is not too sweet with some baking spices and a very nice leather note going on. 
The medium finish let’s you know it’s barrel proof as it goes down. 
I added some water halfway through and that smoothed it out a little, but didn’t really add anything. 
Overall, it’s nice. A little bit on the alcohol fumes side for me. But enjoyable.

Lots of heat on the nose like red hots. A little water tames the heat. Dusty up front followed by brown sugar, minimal fruit. A little orange citrus. Hard to explain but I like it. Lingering brown sugar, cinnamon, touch of orange. The brown sugar sweetness lingers with a long finish and slight oaky bitterness. Unique. Great round mouthfeel. The oaky bitterness for me is keeping it from a higher score. Still highly recommend, especially when on sale
Very satisfying. Quality sipper. Enjoyable all the way through. Sweetness and nuttiness comes through on the palate and finish.
High alcohol content, I need a couple of ice cubes to help mellow it out
Smooth. Smells like rubbing alcohol. Taste like heaven.

I liked this a lot.  Huge value proposition here.

Nose: Dark sugars, vanilla, heavy boiled peanuts, some baking spices, and dried fruit.

Flavor: More dark sugars and boiled peanuts, black licorice and candied nuts.

Finish:  Some rye spice and more peanut and dark sugars.  Medium length.

This tastes a lot like Elijah Craig Barrel Strength but dialed down a little which makes sense given that this is rumored to be a Heaven Hill product and is charcoal mellowed.  VERY good for the price tag.
Nutty and sweet to start, nice burn and honey finish. Great pour.

nose-smooth- light- fruit -Orange- 
Taste-Lots of leather - strong Oak-spice -some anise- 
Finish-wood- spice- short for the proof. 
Overall good- but not something I need to have very often-
A little spicy. Citrusy? Long soft finish. Tasted with one cube.
Really solid bourbon. Good price good juice. Rich deep color and flavor.

A nice high proofer with that signature “nutty” finish...much like Heaven Hill BiB.

Growing on me with every pour.

Nose: spice, Berry tartness and some vanilla in the nose with slight licorice 

Taste: mellow for the high proof, heavy vanilla taste with some chocolate bitterness

Finish: lingering chocolate and Berry finish

Nose: cinnamon vanilla caramel
Body: full
Palate: cinnamon, vanilla, orange, 
Finish: medium long warming
Note: at browns ravens, good. Tingled mouth

Honey, spice, super faint nutty, sharp flavour but quite smooth for barrel proof (but still packs a punch). Notes from memory a couple months ago. Pairs really well with snack foods like cured meats, chocolate, chocolate ice cream.

Have a slight cold so I can’t go into great detail but I do get slight char similar to a very lightly peated scotch mostly noticeable in the finish. Overall extremely well balanced and easily drinkable especially for the high ABV.

N: caramel, banana, vanilla, toffee
P: brown sugar, butter, cinnamon
F: long and steady
Needs time to not burn as much
Wonderful thick mouthfeel. Sweetness. Corn. Oak. Medium burn. Finishes dry. Slight maple.
With a couple of drops of water I get cherry followed by vanilla and a touch of oak.
Definitely get the anise flavor, I had to read the review to get the cherry but I do notice it. Water helps this one, pre water I was getting strong tobacco, dilution helped a lot

Smells of well made Carmel, some spice, vanilla, oak, and raisin?

Taste is spicy but good. A little thin, some good heat and nose burn.
Oak, caramel, and nutmeg. A brighter citrus finish and a litter buttery.

N: Sweet, caramel, vanilla
P:  Spicy, cinnamon
F:  Long

Light fruit nose; then fruit, spicy rye, tannic oak (I'm missing the vanilla everyone mentions), burned cereal, anise; followed by a long and not pleasant astringent finish. Not much corn sweetness here. Disappointing, even with some water/ice.
A perfect everyday bourbon that can hold it's own against any moderately priced brand. I mean, the label alone is worth $10, great design!
Sweet and heat.  Great flavor overall.  A little hot alcohol at the end

Nose: Cedar, brown sugar, cocoa powder, baking spices
Palate: Brown sugar, chili powder, vanilla, marzipan
Very long finish

Nose: Vanilla, Toasted Oak, Raisins 

Palate: Spicy, Vanilla, Caramel, Oak, Buttery, Brown Sugar with a finish of Cherry

Finish: Medium to Long
Nutty, vanilla, best with a bit (but not too much) water
Full body Bourbon with hints of caramel and vanilla with a good Kentucky hug! Neat or with a few drops of water!
Puts some hair on your chest
Wow. Lots of flavors. Sweet beginning with caramel, vanilla, butterscotch with many more that will require more tasting to figure them out.
Hot going down but it has a good burn. I put more ice in than usual. On a cold night it will warm up from the inside.
Tastes like an upscale Jim Beam
Need to order it with a big rock next time. A little too hot for neat.
I like the barrel strength heat, but there isn’t much complexity here. Brown sugar and cinnamon.
Barrel pick from my local bourbon group. Fantastic bourbon. Sweet, vanilla, decent spice but not overwhelming
Liking this one. For 117 has a nice burn but not too much. Nice notes of burnt caramel, vanilla, oak and spice.
Well, balanced bourbon.  Heavy oak and stone fruit, high proof and medium-length finish.
Very vanilla forward. Notes of charcoal and slight heat.  But at 117 proof, absolutely delicious.  Highly recommend this stuff.

Nose: corn, oak
Palate: corn, oak

This is excellently done! Though the bourbon purists will hit on it for still being sourced it is hard not to appreciate this pour. And as a note their distillery is complete and they are patiently waiting for their first bottled offering to come of age. Verdict: sweet on the nose, get the proof on the palate, mild finish (roasted peanuts/peanut butter) ranked top 20 in whiskey advocate 2019. Expect this to continue to fly off shelves. It is a must have in the barrell proof collection with a lower proof than the bigger named barrell proof offerings on the market. Search for it at retail. An inflated price has already taken over in places.
Hot, Spicy, Peanuts. Very good. Similar to JDBP but lower proof. Very enjoyable, will buy this every time I see it for Retail.

Nose started out sweet, then cinnamon, vanilla notes.  Wonderful aroma. Taste of cinnamon, vanilla, buttery, and wood. Nice finish is warm, chocolate, and buttery. Agree with whiskey advocate who rates as a top 20 and at a 94.
Smooth butter, banana ... spicy bite at the back end with almost a smoky aftertaste
A little spicy and nice finish. Would buy again for the right price.
Very different but an easy drinker. Nice spice, deep flavor, very subtle burn.
Very mild burn for the proof, good flavor and body

Color: fantastic copper brown that epitomizes the color bourbon

Legs: there is an initial set that run down the sides, followed by a second grouping lingering at the top

Nose: toasted caramel and toffee with vanilla

Body: the body stays true to the nose and brings a little heat with the 117 proof coming into play

Finish: first sip is spicy and warm with the second and third bring much more gentle.  

Overall: this is a high quality, high proof single barrel with really consistent nose to finish. Sometimes you're in the mood for a surprise, and sometimes you just want to know exactly what you're going to get. This falls in the second category.  Definitely going on my best under $50 list.
Grain, rye spice, cherries. Some heat.

Nice vanilla and sweet notes.  For me no water needed, I do have a water back. 
I normally need to add a little water over 50% ABV.  This is delicious if you can find it.
Great grab at Engel’s! Lots of vanilla flavors on the rocks.

Marketing works on this gem. The bottle and label just look like they belong on some wild west saloon bar. Took me awhile to land a bottle since that just seems to be how it goes with everything once it gets a little fanfare. Hoping this lives up to the hunt. 

Nose is mix of brown sugar and nuts. I dare say it smells a bit like a fresh baked cookie and who doesn't love a good cookie? Taking a sip and that nut flavor comes on strong washing over like a peanut butter flood. The finish takes an interesting turn. Call me crazy, but I get cinnamon apple pie on the moderate burn.  This is a bit of a wild ride, but like a good roller coaster is one I want to ride over and over. Solid juice here that I will definitely search out again!
Similar notes to Elijah Craig barrel proof but a little less bold and with more vanilla sweetness. Really tastes like it is sourced from heaven hill. Delicious bourbon.

Nose - (w/o water) Sweet caramel, oaky cinnamon, light cherry cough drop sweet, oaky vanilla (w/ water) Reduced fruity sweetness, more oaky vanilla caramel

Taste - (w/o water) Mellow, kind of drying cinnamon caramel, light cherry candy, drying oaky vanilla caramel (w/ water) Reduced heat, more dry, less cherry & more oaky cinnamon caramel, fruity sweet reappears at the very end

Finish - (w/o water) Lingering heat/tingle, sweet cherry caramel, cinnamon red hot heat (w/ water) Little to no burn, lingering fruity/cherry lingers, vanilla caramels remain in background

Score - 88/100

Final Thoughts - This one surprised me quite a bit as it wasn't quite as hot as the proof would make you think, which is quite dangerous. I'm mixed about how this handles water in that the mouthfeel is improved, but the cherry is a bit mellowed out. It does help the heat/tingle a bit but it also wasn't that bad for the higher proof in the first place. This isn't too bad for the price but I can see this being quite dangerous as it drinks well below its proof.

Would I drink it if offered? - Yes

Would I specifically order it? - Maybe

Would I buy a bottle? - Yes

Nose is cereals, oatmeal, cinnamon, vanilla and peanut butter.

Palate gets kicked with the heat. Hints of chocolate and tobacco. Relatively short finish. 

I use the rating scale below. Distiller uses a scale of 5 and I use a scale of 10, but I’m sure you’re not too drunk to do the math! 

1. Disgusting - So bad I poured it out.
2. Poor - I wouldn't consume by choice.
3. Bad - Multiple flaws.
4. Below average - Not bad, but many things I'd rather have.
5. Good - Just average.
6. Very Good - Better than average.
7. Great - Well above average.
8. Excellent - In a league of its own.
9. Incredible - An all-time favorite.
10. Perfect

I must have a one-off odd bottling because the flavor profile of this bourbon is unlike any I've tasted before, and after reading others' tastings, I feel like I'm not drinking the same juice. The nose is wet wood and moss. The flavor is like scooping fire water out of the base of a dead tree in the forest. And none of that is a bad thing! Like squeezing the water out of damp mulch, then fermenting it.  Amazing and weird. Anyone else get this flavor profile?
Amazing bourbon nutty flavor super smooth. Very under rated

Nose is deep and dark. Dark cherry, dark chocolate, dark malted cereal grain. Almond, anise, caramel, and old book shelf notes really round out the brooding nose. 

Caramel buttered biscuits and orange marmalade starts off. Marzipan, peanut butter, and oak lead way to vanilla, cinnamon, and cherry on the lengthy finish. Smooth, with just a little burn. Tame for a barrel proof.

This indeed would be a great bourbon for a cold winter's night. Lots of festive flavors. I mean, don't get me wrong, I will enjoy this all year.
A winter bourbon. Warm and spicy, with more clove than cinnamon. Deep and rich. Beautiful dark rum color, thick mouth feel. 117 proof without too much heat.
Each time I have this I really enjoy it. It’s become one of my favorites.
Drinking with Jeff during Covid on my property boundary. Socially distanced.
Honey color. Ethanol on the nose. Red apple. Very sweet with a burn on the back. Syrupy burn
Pretty good. A little more age might drop the amount of bite.
Not sure I would buy this again... hoping it opens up more

About halfway through my open bottle and decided to revisit.

NOSE: Leather, Old Oak, Orange Peel, Corn Dust, Peanut Shell, Light Vanilla Sweetness, and a good bit of Heat.
NEAT: Oily and Sticky. Licorice, Clove, Orange Oil, Slightly Bitter Oak. A building KY Hug grows in the chest after a long-ish finish that leaves Bitter Oak and Citrus coating the palate.
SPLASH: Opens it up nicely. Adds some Cinnamon to the nose and Peanut Brittle and Cinnamon to the palate. Tames the astringency and gives the finish a Musty Old Oak character.
VERDICT: This one has held up well. Really needs a little water for maximum enjoyment. A solid 4
Lots of heat, light bodied, great after taste.
Real hot neat. Would absolutely buy again at $50
Mid-high proof brings forth cherry, brown sugar candy, high spice finish
Spicy notes at first but with a sweet smooth finish
Very spicy! Long finish. Lots of Star anis, Cherry, cinnamon, and cocoa powder.

On the nose, you get the usual suspects of vanilla and caramel, but can't really say anything worth noting came out.⠀
⠀
The first hit to the palate gave me a nice surprise of heat, like when you are looking at your phone while lying in bed, and you accidentally drop it on your face. I admit, I didn't really look at the bottle before pouring this one, so I was not expecting 117 proof. The high proof almost masked the flavors at first, but once it settles you get a decent blend of sweet fruit, caramel and oak, followed by a very long finish with more oak and some strong spice flavors.⠀
Nice bold flavors of charred oak, vanilla, a hint of cherry, and maybe some anise.
Very oaky and tannic. Drop or two of water opens the sweeter notes nicely.

Nose - vanilla and ethanol
Palate - intense vanilla  and graham cracker. Fades into slight menthol mouth feel.
Finish - very short. Slight leather and dark chocolate with lingering menthol feel on the tongue. 
Tier 2
Carmel, sweet, spices with a bit of punch
Definitely solid. Lots of flavors going on actually, I can't even pick them all out. Curious to see how this does once it airs out a bit.

A Vanilla cream nose, very enticing.  
First taste - a little harsh, but probably due to the high proof.  Has a dark fruit taste, almost chocolate.
Aftertaste - I get peanut butter predominantly.
I like this and will definitely be drinking more.

Nose: Heat, caramel, vanilla, whisps of lemon on a quick sniff, crackerjacks, brown sugar

Taste: oak and spice upfront turns into caramel peanut crackerjack, vanilla, peanut flavor seems to linger - maybe because I don’t often get this 

Lasting warming finish 

Somehow after a few mins I have taste of fresh cut grass on the palate

Nose: chocolate
Palette: More chocolate!
Finish: a nice hug. Chocolate fades and you get the oak and a bit of spices
Spicy up front with a smooth finish that lingers
Almost tasted like a straight rye to me.  Not my cup of tea.  Didn't live up to the hype.
Great value. A little funky but good.
Smell of strong cherry, oak, vanilla. Taste matches, with the addition of baking spice that holds on for a medium finish. Easy drinking for the 117 proof.

Neat. Opened more than 6 months.  Recall loving this the first time I had it but it has been so long I can’t recall the profile other than being nutty life a high proof Heaven Hill.

On the nose, those peanuts reign supreme.  It’s like a creamy peanut butter.  Hint of toffee and mint.  Some nice barrel char.  Baking spices.  The peanut butter subsides the longer I sit with it and it has plenty of flavors to pick out behind it.  Starting to get some milk chocolate and sweetness.

Mouth feel is perfect, so creamy.  All cinnamon and brown sugar at first.  Ah, the flavors are fantastic.  The taste exceeds the nose.  Chocolate, peanut butter and toffee are there but then some vanilla and apple.  Nice oak presence on the legs.  Decent amount of brine on there.  Nice caramel drizzle coming through on those apples.  It is a bit more tannic and drying than I would have expected out of a 7 year.

Mmm this is a delicious pour.  Clearly forgot how good this was.  The nose is a bit generic and boring but the taste is fantastic, crisp, creamy, and rich.  Really enjoying this today.
My everyday drink lately. Good full flavor
